results.title: Bushed
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Steve French
results.brief_description: An animated story about a displaced Aboriginal who meets a misplaced kangaroo. Together they “travel the bush of Australia like true-born native men”. But the bush has changed and they discover that “you can’t go home again”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Steve French

results.title: Bushcraft
results.brief_description: Before setting out on a camping trip, careful planning is necessary. The film demonstrates the choice of equipment, the proper food and clothing required and how a rucksack should be packed. For the trip itself, other hints include the various ways to cross a river, finding the route, marking the trail, building a fire and the correct handling of firearms.

results.title: Bush tucker man
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Defence and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: The Australian Army’s botanist, Major Les Hiddins is studying the natural survival resources of the vast wilderness of northern Australia. This study takes into account the native bush foods and medicines that have sustained Aboriginal people and is the first study of its kind since European settlement. It provides valuable information for Australian soldiers should they ever have to survive in such an inhospitable region. Some unique flora is also discovered. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Bush policemen
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Stanley Hawes and Lee Robinson
results.brief_description: The bush policeman’s beat, in the vast inland of Australia, takes him through strange and sometimes un-mapped places, to preserve law and order on the fringes of civilization. As the Mountie is to north-west Canada, so is the bush policeman to the wild, tropical north-west of Australia.

results.title: Bush pilot: reflections on a Canadian myth
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott, Bob Lower and Norma Bailey
results.brief_description: For some bush pilots, flying is like playing solo violin at Carnegie Hall. For others, it’s like driving a taxi. This film shows how bush pilots are slowly being replaced. In northern towns built by bulldozers and jet aircraft, the emphasis is not on adapting to the north, but on remaking it in the image of the south. This is a thought provoking film about northern development.

results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Warlpiri Media, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Jennifer McMahon, David Batty and Francis Jupurrula Kelly
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: Bush Mechanics animation (2015)
results.brief_description: In the central Australian desert, four Warlpiri men travel to visit a powerful elder at a remote outstation. On the road they must overcome mechanical mishaps and the trickery of a mischievous spirit. It will take all of their bush ingenuity to keep their car running and themselves alive.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

results.title: Bush mechanics (A)
results.creator_credit: Waripiri Media, Tom Kantor, David Batty and Francis Kelly
results.brief_description: A documentary that takes a light-hearted look at the ingenious methods that Aboriginal men living in remote communities employ to keep their automobiles running. Without a trade certificate between them, these men have developed the unique craft of ‘bush mechanics’, adapting available resources for use as spare parts. The stories they relate provide a unique insight into this practical and philosophical approach to car maintenance and highlight many of the adaptive techniques desert people have developed through necessity over the last seventy years.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Waripiri Media, Tom Kantor, David Batty and Francis Kelly

results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

results.description:
David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) only ran for one season, but it became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience, where nyurulypa (good tricks) are used to keep wrecked cars on the red—sand roads of outback Australia. The cast use mulga wood, spinifex and clever hacks to showcase their ingenious approach to mechanics.

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.

“The core of Bush Mechanics was basically a road trip, where you had the crappest car in the world, and things would inevitably go wrong… so you have to innovate… things like stuffing a flat tyre with spinifex… or getting a tree and carving it to make a crankshaft. It became like a cult classic. It took the country, in a very quiet way, by storm.” – Rachel Perkins
description_for_label:

The cast use mulga wood, spinifex and clever hacks to showcase their ingenious approach to mechanics.

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.

It became like a cult classic. It took the country, in a very quiet way, by storm.” – Rachel Perkins
